notesStmt.note: Whitman's note in the top margin of the recto suggests this manuscript was composed in January 1863. Union soldier Thomas A. Morrison was injured December 13, 1862, at the Battle of Fredericksburg, and he was hospitalized in Washington beginning as early as late December 1862. He remained there until he was discharged in late April 1863, when he returned to his native Pennsylvania (Charles Blanchard, ed., "Judge Thomas Anderson Morrison," The Progressive Men of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania [Logansport, IN: A. W. Bowen & Co., 1900], 2:534–537).

body.p: Thos A. Morrison, Co. A, 121st Penn is a young fellow, 22 yrs old from Vraised in Holland, Venango county, Penn. cam join came in service in August '62—was at Fredericksburgh, was wounded early in the morning of the battle—had his arm amputated on the field, taken off close up to the shoulder, (hasn't a smitch of arm left)—when wounded, was carried to the rear to the river and operation performed—lay on the field Satu all day Saturday, all Saturday night, and all Sunday—then carried over to the Falmouth side, lay in hospital tent there awhile, (no weak, little or no consciousness, too insensible much stupor to suffer any great pain,)—just remembers being carried to the cars,—it is like a dream—on the boat from Aquia creek the same. Had $30 he had saved; some thief stole it on the journey. Was pale, feeble, exhausted, just alive, but soon began to pick up slowly—has got along very well, but h a tough siege of it
